stem: The burn intensive care nurse is calculating fluid requirements for a client with 40% TBSA burns. Based on the documentation in the Parkland Formula Calculator log, match each clinical period with the correct fluid administration goal.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient: (Mr. Davis, 80kg). Sustained 40% TBSA deep partial-thickness burns at 10:00. 
11:00: Arrived at the ED. 
Physician's Orders: Resuscitate using Parkland Formula (4 mL/kg/%TBSA) with Lactated Ringer's (LR).

tabs.title: Parkland Formula Calculator & Hourly Output
tabs.content:
Calculation ComponentValue
Total 24-hr Fluid (80kg * 40% * 4mL)12,800 mL
Target Output (0.5 mL/kg/hr)40 mL/hr
First 8-Hour Goal (from 10:00 to 18:00)6,400 mL
Second 16-Hour Goal (from 18:00 to 10:00)6,400 mL

tabs.title: Vital Signs & Output
tabs.content: Current Time: 12:00. Urine output for last hour: 22 mL (Low). MAP 60.

rows.text: Total fluid volume to be given in the first 24 hours
Volume to be given in the first 8 hours (Calculated from time of injury)
Preferred fluid for resuscitation in the first 24 hours
The primary indicator of successful fluid resuscitation

rationale.correct: The total volume is 12,800 mL (r1/c1). Parkland requires half of this (6,400 mL) in the first 8 hours (r2/c2). Lactated Ringer's is the fluid of choice (r3/c3) because it mimics body chemistry. The gold standard for success is urine output (r4/c4).
clinicalPearls: The 8-hour clock starts at the TIME OF INJURY, not when the patient arrived at the hospital.
LR is used to prevent metabolic acidosis in burn victims.
Weight is the most important variable in the Parkland formula.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the first 8 hours starts when the IV is inserted.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always Subtract the time already passed! If the injury was at 10:00 and the IV started at 12:00, you have to give the first half of the fluid in 6 hours, not 8.

mnemonic.title: Burn 4
mnemonic.expansion: 4 mL x Weight x Burn %. (The number 4 is key in Parkland).
